recommended_movies: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)

simulated_ratings.title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Inventive heartbreak and tender what-ifs hit my sweet spot of romantic melancholy and mind-bendy storytelling.

simulated_ratings.title: Her (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Intimate, thoughtful sci-fi romance that made me feel seen and a little lonely in the best way.

simulated_ratings.title: Before Sunrise (1995)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Wandering conversation and instant connection—exactly the kind of talky, wistful romance I savor.

simulated_ratings.title: Before Sunset (2004)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sharper, more mature sparks and aching honesty—utterly absorbing.

simulated_ratings.title: Before Midnight (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Piercing, lived-in relationship conflict that stings but still feels humane.

simulated_ratings.title: The Handmaiden (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Devious, sensual, and brilliantly plotted—kept me grinning through every twist.

simulated_ratings.title: Parasite (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Propulsive, darkly funny class thriller that grips and surprises without losing heart.

simulated_ratings.title: Memories of Murder (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Atmospheric, haunting procedural with moral weight that lingers long after.

simulated_ratings.title: Burning (2018)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Mesmerizing ambiguity and slow-burn tension, though the distance kept me slightly at arm’s length.

simulated_ratings.title: Prisoners (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Relentless, morally knotted thriller that had me clenched and conflicted throughout.

simulated_ratings.title: Nightcrawler (2014)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Slick, unnerving character study with razor-edged satire I couldn’t look away from.

simulated_ratings.title: The Nice Guys (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Breezy, quippy buddy-mystery with just enough heart to balance the goofiness.

simulated_ratings.title: Seven Psychopaths (2012)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Meta crime caper with jagged humor I enjoyed, if not as deeply as darker, more grounded entries I love.

simulated_ratings.title: The Banshees of Inisherin (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Bleakly funny and tender in its own way, though the bitterness kept me a touch removed.

simulated_ratings.title: The Station Agent (2003)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Quiet, compassionate found-family story that hits my indie-dramedy sweet spot.

simulated_ratings.title: Hunt for the Wilderpeople (2016)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Warm, witty odd-couple adventure with real heart beneath the hijinks.

simulated_ratings.title: The Big Sick (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Smart, heartfelt culture-clash romance that’s both funny and genuinely moving.

simulated_ratings.title: Call Me by Your Name (2017)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Sun-drenched, aching first love that lingers with delicate, lived-in emotion.

simulated_ratings.title: Portrait of a Lady on Fire (2019)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gorgeously restrained and emotionally volcanic—a slow burn that really pays off.

simulated_ratings.title: Brooklyn (2015)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Classic, tender romance about choice and home that felt comforting and sincere.

simulated_ratings.title: The Lunchbox (2013)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Gentle, letter-born intimacy that blossoms into something quietly profound.

simulated_ratings.title: Once (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Unadorned musical romance whose songs and tentative connection feel beautifully authentic.

simulated_ratings.title: The Secret in Their Eyes (2009)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Elegant, emotionally charged mystery where longing and justice tangle grippingly.

simulated_ratings.title: Zodiac (2007)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Immersive, meticulous investigation that hypnotized me with dread and obsession.

simulated_ratings.title: Headhunters (2011)
simulated_ratings.feeling: Lean, twisty crime fun—clever and tense even if the sheen outweighs the soul.

simulated_ratings.title: Victoria (2015)

simulated_ratings.title: The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014)

simulated_ratings.title: Glass Onion: A Knives Out Mystery (2022)
simulated_ratings.feeling: A slick, lively puzzle I enjoyed, even if the character warmth isn’t as rich for me.
